Topic.Title: everybody is talking about buybacks, they mean nothing unless they retire the shares, do you all understand that

Message.Msg: A buyback does nothing for the share price. You will get fewer shares and each share representing a larger part of the company but the company is worth less. Yahoo loses value by buying and retiring shares. The cash used is no longer a part of Yahoo. Just like the last $3 billion buyback did nothing for the share price. Driving the share price artificially up by buying shares is also impossible since Yahoo can only buy at last price or lower.

Topic.Title: Buyback-Float - Decison -

Message.Msg: One feature about a stock buyback, that, to me, is a benefit for the current share holder is that unlike a dividend, I can plan my own tax consequenses. I can time my tax liability to meet my individual tax needs. I am all for a significent stock buy back beyond the $600 plus million already executed.

Topic.Title: everybody is talking about buybacks, they mean nothing unless they retire the shares, do you all understand that

Message.Msg: Many share buy backs do help stock price. AOL's sure did. It has to be a big and well directed buy back, (Dutch aution?). With interest rates so low, (i.e. YHOO can't earn much on cash and can borrow cheaply) and YHOO having assets that they don't seem to get fair market credit for (i.e. undervalued) to buy back shares at this level would be a big boost. Obviously less shares outstanding means higher earnings per share and ergo share price with the same PE.

Topic.Title: everybody is talking about buybacks, they mean nothing unless they retire the shares, do you all understand that

Message.Msg: AOL was up before the announced buyback and dividend and did not move on the announcement but may drop $5 when the dividend is paid. Dutch auction is the same as buyback + dividend, after the auction the company is worth less and that value is reflected in the share price. There is no magic formula for Yahoo to give you money without losing value. One way or another you pay for every dollar Yahoo gives you. ItÂ´s not free money.

Topic.Title: everybody is talking about buybacks, they mean nothing unless they retire the shares, do you all understand that

Message.Msg: I don't think its true that AOL moved before buyback was known. So you think AOL got free money to make it move up so much ? Why did they move so far up after deal was announced? YHOO would not be giving us money, they would be buying back their undervalued shares and lowering the float and PE ratio.

Topic.Title: everybody is talking about buybacks, they mean nothing unless they retire the shares, do you all understand that

Message.Msg: AOL sold patents for more than the market had thought them worth. YHOO would not be giving us money, they would be buying back their undervalued shares, lowering the value of Yahoo and lowering the float and PE ratio making the shareholder no better or worse of than before.

Topic.Title: everybody is talking about buybacks, they mean nothing unless they retire the shares, do you all understand that

Message.Msg: How much more did AOL get for patents than market thought they were worth? Why were AOL's worth so much yet you and the market seem to give YHOO so little value for a much bigger patent portfolio? So much for efficient market. AOL went from something like $15 to $36. I don't think they got $20/share for the patents.

Topic.Title: everybody is talking about buybacks, they mean nothing unless they retire the shares, do you all understand that

Message.Msg: Buybacks only make sense when the stock being bought back is a dividend paying stock where the payout yield is greater than the interest earned on the cash on hand or the interest paid on money borrowed to do the buyback.

Message.Title: Bullish Piper Note basis for today's move (Gene Munster analyst)
Message.Msg: 10/3 prior to open CONCLUSION: Based on our daily ad checks in September, we believe that 89% of Yahoo!'s homepage inventory was sold on a guaranteed basis, compared to 65% last September and 43% in August. It is also the highest rating we have seen since Q4 2010. We currently expect 4% Y/Y net display growth in Q3 (1% Q/Q decline) and we remain comfortable with our projection, but note there may be upside from Olympic/Election impact in the quarter. While it is only one month of significant improvement, we believe the core business may be showing some signs of turning around under new leadership. to 71% in August and 65% last Sept
